revisions.rev:
{{NCAATeamFootballSeason |Year=2004 |Team=Iowa Hawkeyes |Image= |ImageSize= |Conference=Big Ten Conference |Division= |ShortConference=Big Ten |CoachRank=8 |APRank=8 |Record=10-2 |ConfRecord=7-1 |HeadCoach=[[Kirk Ferentz]] |OffCoach=[[Ken O'Keefe]] |DefCoach=Norm Parker |OScheme= |DScheme= |StadiumArena=[[Kinnick Stadium]] |Champion=Big Ten Co-Champions
Capital One Bowl Champions |BowlTourney=[[2005 Capital One Bowl|Capital One Bowl]] |BowlTourneyResult=W 30-25 vs. [[2004 LSU Tigers football team|LSU]] }} The '''2004 Iowa Hawkeyes football team''' represented the [[University of Iowa]] in the [[2004 NCAA Division I-A football season|2004 college football season]]. They played their home games in [[Kinnick Stadium]] and were coached by [[Kirk Ferentz]]. Finishing the 2003 season with a 10-3 record and an [[2004 Outback Bowl|Outback Bowl]] victory, the Hawkeyes began the season 2-0 with wins over {{cfb link|year=2004|team=Kent State Golden Flashes|title=Kent State}} and {{cfb link|year=2004|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}}.{{cite web|title = Iowa 2004 Football Schedule / Results |url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/teamsched?teamId=2294&year=2004 |publisher = ESPN |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-12 }} But after rocky performances at [[2004 Arizona State Sun Devils football team|Arizona State]] and [[2004 Michigan Wolverines football team|Michigan]], the Hawkeyes sat at 2-2 going into their game with [[2004 Michigan State Spartans football team|Michigan State]]. The Hawkeyes handily defeated the Spartans 38–16,{{cite web|title = Iowa 38, Michigan State 16 |url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/100204aac.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com |date = 2004-10-02 |accessdate = 2007-08-12 }} and turned their attention to [[2004 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]], a team whom the Hawkeyes had not beaten at home since 1983.{{cite web|title = Iowa 33, No. 23 Ohio State 7 |url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/101604aaa.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com |date = 2004-10-16 |accessdate = 2007-08-12 }} Behind a strong [[American football strategy#Defensive strategy|defensive]] performance that allowed only 177 yards,{{cite web|title = Iowa Cruises Past No. 25 Ohio State, 33-7 |url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/101604aab.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com |date = 2004-10-16 |accessdate = 2007-08-12 }} the Hawkeyes easily defeated the Buckeyes by 26 points, the largest margin of victory over Ohio State in Iowa history. However, tragedy struck soon thereafter, when [[head coach]] Kirk Ferentz's father died.{{cite web|title = Ferentz's Father Passes Away |url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/102004aac.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com |date = 2004-10-20 |accessdate = 2007-08-12 }} In the emotional game that ensued, the Hawkeyes narrowly defeated [[2004 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]] 6–4 on two Kyle Schlicher [[Field goal (football)|field goals]].{{cite web|title = Wine Online: A Defense Battle |url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/102404aac.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com / George Wine |date = 2004-10-24 |accessdate = 2007-08-12 }} The Hawkeyes then raised their record to 8-2 with victories over {{cfb link|year=2004|team=Illinois Fighting Illini|title=Illinois}}, [[2004 Purdue Boilermakers football team|Purdue]], and [[2004 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]]. With a share of the [[Big Ten]] [[Big Ten Conference football champions|championship]] on the line, the Hawkeyes met [[2004 Wisconsin Badgers football team|Wisconsin]] in the final regular season game of the year. Iowa won the game,{{cite web|title = Iowa 30, Wisconsin 7 |url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/112004aab.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com |date = 2004-11-20 |accessdate = 2007-08-12 }} and thousands of Hawkeye fans swarmed the field in celebration.{{cite web|title = Wisconsin vs. Iowa |url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores104/104325/20041120NCAAFIOWA------0nr.htm#RCPS |publisher = USA Today |date = 2004-11-20 |accessdate = 2007-08-12 }} Several weeks following the victory, Iowa accepted a bid to play the [[2004 LSU Tigers football team|LSU Tigers]] in the [[2005 Capital One Bowl]].{{cite web|title = Iowa Faces "Tough Draw" |url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/120404aaa.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com |date = 2004-12-04 |accessdate = 2007-08-12 }} In a game that was originally thought to be a defensive matchup,{{cite web|title = Capital One Bowl Breakdown |url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/football/ncaa/specials/bowls/2004/12/29/capitalone.breakdown/index.html |publisher = SI.com |date = 2004-12-29 |accessdate = 2007-08-12 }} the Hawkeyes took a 24–12 lead early in the fourth quarter. But behind [[freshman]] [[quarterback]] [[JaMarcus Russell]], the Tigers stormed back, and took a one-point lead with 46 seconds remaining.{{cite web|title = Iowa vs. Louisiana State |url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores105/105001/20050101NCAAFLSU-------0nr.htm |publisher = USA Today |date = 2005-01-02 |accessdate = 2007-08-12 }} However, LSU's comeback was all for naught, as Iowa's [[Drew Tate]] completed a 56-yard [[touchdown]] pass to [[Warren Holloway]] as time expired, giving Iowa the 30–25 win and a 10-2 final record. == Previous season == {{main|2003 Iowa Hawkeyes football team}} In 2003, Iowa began the season 4-0{{cite web|title = No. 14 Iowa 21, No. 16 Arizona State 2 |url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/092003aab.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com |date = 2003-09-20 |accessdate = 2007-08-13 }} and would eventually complete the regular season with a 9-3 record that included wins over Iowa State, Michigan (Iowa's second straight victory against Michigan), and Minnesota. {{cite web|title = 2003 Big Ten results |url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/college/football/bigten/03recap.htm |publisher = USA Today |date = 2004-05-01 |accessdate = 2007-08-13 }} However, the Hawkeyes lost to Michigan State, Ohio State, and Purdue. Finishing fourth in the Big Ten standings,{{cite web|title = FINAL - Big Ten Football Standings |url = http://www.goldfan.com/bigten/2003/bigten_1207.shtml |publisher = GoldFan.com |date = 2004-01-05 |accessdate = 2007-08-13 }} the Hawkeyes accepted a bid to play the [[2003 Florida Gators football team|Florida Gators]] in the Outback Bowl.{{cite web|title = It's Tampa! |url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/120703aac.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com |date = 2003-12-07 |accessdate = 2007-08-13 }} Despite falling behind early on a 70-yard touchdown pass from [[Chris Leak]] to Kelvin Knight, the Hawkeyes reeled off 27 straight points en route to a 37–17 victory.{{cite web|title = Iowa vs. Florida |url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores104/104001/20040101NCAAFFLORIDA---0nr.htm |publisher = USA Today |date = 2004-01-01 |accessdate = 2007-08-13 }} It was a milestone victory, as it gave Iowa its second consecutive 10-win season along with the first Hawkeye victory in a January bowl game since the [[1958 Iowa Hawkeyes football team#Postseason|Rose Bowl]] in 1959. Following the season, five Iowa players were selected in the [[2004 NFL Draft]].{{cite web|title = Gallery Second Overall Pick at NFL Draft |url = http://hawkeyesports.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/042404aaa.html |publisher = HawkeyeSports.com |date = 2004-04-24 |accessdate = 2007-08-13 }} [[Robert Gallery]], the 2003 [[Outland Trophy]] winner, became the second-highest pick in school history when he was selected 2nd by the [[Oakland Raiders]]. Following Gallery in Iowa's draft order were [[Bob Sanders]], taken 44th by [[Indianapolis Colts|Indianapolis]], [[Nate Kaeding]], taken 65th by [[San Diego Chargers|San Diego]], [[Jared Clauss]], taken in the seventh round by [[Tennessee Titans|Tennessee]], and Erik Jensen, who was taken in the seventh round by [[St. Louis Rams|St. Louis]]. == Before the season == Prior to the season, the Hawkeyes looked to replace seven offensive starters and four defensive starters.{{cite web|title = EARLY BIRD 2004 COLLEGE FOOTBALL PREVIEW - #18 Iowa Hawkeyes |url = http://www.nationalchamps.net/2004/earlybird/teams/iowa.htm |publisher = NationalChamps.net |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-13 }} Key losses from 2003 included Maurice Brown, Robert Gallery, Nate Chandler, [[Fred Russell (football player)|Fred Russell]], and Ramon Ochoa on offense. Defensively, the Hawkeyes looked to replace Howard Hodges, Jared Clauss, Grant Steen, and Bob Sanders. Replacement starters on offense were Drew Tate, Champ Davis, Jermelle Lewis, Calvin Davis, Tony Jackson, Lee Gray, Mike Elgin, and Chris Felder.{{cite web|title = Iowa 2004 Football Preview |url = http://nationalchamps.net/2004/sub/previews/iowa.htm |publisher = NationalChamps.net |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-13 }} On defense, [[Derreck Robinson]], Tyler Luebke, George Lewis, and Marcus Paschal assumed their roles on the starting lineup. On special teams, David Bradley returned for his senior season as [[Punter (American football)|punter]], while Kyle Schlicher replaced Nate Kaeding as the starting kicker. === Rankings === * NationalChamps.net - 12th * USA Today - 12th{{cite web|title = 2004 NCAA Football Rankings - Week 1 |url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/rankingsindex?pollId=null&seasonYear=2004&weekNumber=1 |publisher = ESPN.com |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-13 }} * SI.com - 15th{{cite web|title = Sports Illustrated's 2004 Scouting Reports |url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/magazine/08/10/main/ |publisher = SI.com |date = 2004-08-16 |accessdate = 2007-08-13 }} * AP Top 25 - 19th === Recruiting class === Iowa signed 21 players on [[National Signing Day]], which was February 4, 2004. The Hawkeyes added another commit to the class with the late addition of defensive lineman Ettore Ewen.{{cite web|title = Ettore Ewen Profile |url = http://www.rivals.com/viewprospect.asp?Sport=1&pr_key=29825 |publisher = Rivals.com|date = |accessdate = 2007-08-13 }} Another recruit, Kyle Williams, later de-committed from the Hawkeyes and committed to the Purdue Boilermakers.{{cite web|title = Kyle Williams to head to Purdue |url = http://media.www.dailyiowan.com/media/storage/paper599/news/2004/10/19/Sports/Kyle-Williams.To.Head.To.Purdue-772568.shtml |publisher = The Daily Iowan |date = 2004-10-19 |accessdate = 2007-08-14 }} 13th{{cite web|title = 2004 Schedule Strength And Official School Websites |url = http://www.footballfantasy.com/2004_Schedule_Strength_And_Official_School_Websites.htm |publisher = FootballFantasy.com |date = |accessdate = 2007-08-14 }} * Russell Rankings -
